These boreholes perhaps reached a depth of 600 m (2000 ft).
Mechanical and hydraulic engineering.
Han-era mechanical engineering comes largely from the choice observational writings of sometimes-disinterested Confucian scholars who generally considered scientific and engineering endeavors to be far beneath them. Professional artisan-engineers ("jiang" 匠) did not leave behind detailed records of their work. Han scholars, who often had little or no expertise in mechanical engineering, sometimes provided insufficient information on the various technologies they described. Nevertheless, some Han literary sources provide crucial information. 
For example, in 15 BC the philosopher and writer <a href="Yang%20Xiong%20%28author%29">Yang Xiong</a> described the invention of the <a href="Belt%20%28mechanical%29">belt drive</a> for a <a href="quilling">quilling</a> machine, which was of great importance to early textile manufacturing. The inventions of mechanical engineer and craftsman <a href="Ding%20Huan">Ding Huan</a> are mentioned in the "Miscellaneous Notes on the Western Capital". Around AD 180, Ding created a manually operated rotary fan used for <a href="air%20conditioning">air conditioning</a> within palace buildings. Ding also used <a href="gimbal">gimbal</a>s as pivotal supports for one of his incense burners and invented the world's first known <a href="zoetrope">zoetrope</a> lamp.
Modern archeology has led to the discovery of Han artwork portraying inventions which were otherwise absent in Han literary sources. As observed in Han miniature tomb models, but not in literary sources, the <a href="Crank%20%28mechanism%29">crank handle</a> was used to operate the <a href="Fan%20%28mechanical%29">fans</a> of <a href="Fengshanche">winnowing machines</a> that separated grain from <a href="chaff">chaff</a>. The <a href="odometer">odometer</a> cart, invented during Han, measured journey lengths, using mechanical figures banging drums and gongs to indicate each distance traveled. This invention is depicted in Han artwork by the 2nd century, yet detailed written descriptions were not offered until the 3rd century. 
Modern archeologists have also unearthed specimens of devices used during the Han dynasty, for example a pair of sliding metal <a href="caliper">caliper</a>s used by craftsmen for making minute measurements. These calipers contain inscriptions of the exact day and year they were manufactured. These tools are not mentioned in any Han literary sources.
The <a href="waterwheel">waterwheel</a> appeared in Chinese records during the Han. As mentioned by Huan Tan about AD 20, they were used to turn gears that lifted iron <a href="trip%20hammer">trip hammer</a>s, and were used in pounding, <a href="threshing">threshing</a> and polishing grain. However, there is no sufficient evidence for the <a href="watermill">watermill</a> in China until about the 5th century. The <a href="Nanyang%20Commandery">Nanyang Commandery</a> Administrator and mechanical engineer <a href="Du%20Shi">Du Shi</a> (d. 38 AD) created a waterwheel-powered <a href="Reciprocating%20motion">reciprocator</a> that worked the <a href="bellows">bellows</a> for the smelting of iron. Waterwheels were also used to power <a href="chain%20pump">chain pump</a>s that lifted water to raised <a href="irrigation">irrigation</a> ditches. The chain pump was first mentioned in China by the philosopher Wang Chong in his 1st-century "<a href="Lunheng">Balanced Discourse</a>".
The <a href="armillary%20sphere">armillary sphere</a>, a three-dimensional representation of the movements in the <a href="celestial%20sphere">celestial sphere</a>, was invented in Han China by the 1st century BC. Using a <a href="water%20clock">water clock</a>, waterwheel and a series of gears, the Court Astronomer <a href="Zhang%20Heng">Zhang Heng</a> (AD 78–139) was able to mechanically rotate his metal-ringed armillary sphere. To address the problem of slowed <a href="timekeeping">timekeeping</a> in the <a href="pressure%20head">pressure head</a> of the inflow water clock, Zhang was the first in China to install an additional tank between the reservoir and inflow vessel. 
Zhang also invented a device he termed an "earthquake weathervane" ( 候風地動儀), which the British biochemist, sinologist, and historian <a href="Joseph%20Needham">Joseph Needham</a> described as "the ancestor of all <a href="seismographs">seismographs</a>". This device was able to detect the exact <a href="Cardinal%20direction">cardinal</a> or ordinal direction of <a href="earthquake">earthquake</a>s from hundreds of kilometers away. It employed an <a href="inverted%20pendulum">inverted pendulum</a> that, when disturbed by ground tremors, would trigger a set of gears that dropped a metal ball from one of eight dragon mouths (representing all eight directions) into a metal toad's mouth. 
The account of this device in the "<a href="Book%20of%20the%20Later%20Han">Book of the Later Han</a>" describes how, on one occasion, one of the metal balls was triggered without any of the observers feeling a disturbance. Several days later, a messenger arrived bearing news that an earthquake had struck in Longxi Commandery (in modern <a href="Gansu%20Province">Gansu Province</a>), the direction the device had indicated, which forced the officials at court to admit the efficacy of Zhang's device.
Mathematics.
Three Han mathematical treatises still exist. These are the "<a href="Book%20on%20Numbers%20and%20Computation">Book on Numbers and Computation</a>", the "<a href="Zhoubi%20Suanjing">Arithmetical Classic of the Gnomon and the Circular Paths of Heaven</a>" and the "<a href="Nine%20Chapters%20on%20the%20Mathematical%20Art">Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art</a>". Han-era mathematical achievements include solving problems with <a href="Triangle%23Types%20of%20triangle">right-angle triangles</a>, <a href="square%20root">square root</a>s, <a href="cube%20root">cube root</a>s, and <a href="Matrix%20%28mathematics%29">matrix methods</a>, finding more accurate <a href="Chronology%20of%20computation%20of%20%CF%80">approximations for pi</a>, providing <a href="mathematical%20proof">mathematical proof</a> of the <a href="Pythagorean%20theorem">Pythagorean theorem</a>, use of the <a href="Fraction%20%28mathematics%29">decimal fraction</a>, <a href="Gaussian%20elimination">Gaussian elimination</a> to solve <a href="System%20of%20linear%20equations">linear equations</a>, and continued fractions to find the <a href="root%20of%20a%20function">roots of equations</a>.
One of the Han's greatest mathematical advancements was the world's first use of <a href="negative%20number">negative number</a>s. Negative numbers first appeared in the "Nine Chapters on the Mathematical Art" as black <a href="counting%20rods">counting rods</a>, where positive numbers were represented by red counting rods. Negative numbers were also used by the <a href="Greece">Greek</a> mathematician <a href="Diophantus">Diophantus</a> around AD 275, and in the 7th-century <a href="Bakhshali%20manuscript">Bakhshali manuscript</a> of <a href="Gandhara">Gandhara</a>, South Asia, but were not widely accepted in Europe until the 16th century.
The Han applied mathematics to various diverse disciplines. In <a href="musical%20tuning">musical tuning</a>, <a href="Jing%20Fang">Jing Fang</a> (78–37 BC) realized that 53 <a href="perfect%20fifth">perfect fifth</a>s was approximate to 31 <a href="octave">octave</a>s while creating a <a href="musical%20scale">musical scale</a> of 60 tones, calculating the difference at 177147⁄176776 (the same value of <a href="53%20equal%20temperament">53 equal temperament</a> discovered by the German mathematician <a href="Nicholas%20Mercator">Nicholas Mercator</a> [1620–1687], i.e. 353/284).
Astronomy.
Mathematics were essential in drafting the <a href="Chinese%20calendar">astronomical calendar</a>, a <a href="lunisolar%20calendar">lunisolar calendar</a> that used the Sun and Moon as time-markers throughout the year. During the spring and autumn periods of the 5th century BC, the Chinese established the Sifen calendar (古四分历), which measured the <a href="tropical%20year">tropical year</a> at 365.25 days. This was replaced in 104 BC with the Taichu calendar (太初曆) that measured the tropical year at (~ 365.25016) days and the <a href="lunar%20month">lunar month</a> at days. However, Emperor Zhang later reinstated the Sifen calendar.
Han Chinese astronomers made <a href="star%20catalogue">star catalogue</a>s and detailed records of comets that appeared in the night sky, including recording the 12 BC appearance of the comet now known as <a href="Halley%27s%20Comet">Halley's Comet</a>.
Han dynasty astronomers adopted a <a href="geocentric%20model">geocentric model</a> of the universe, theorizing that it was <a href="celestial%20sphere">shaped like a sphere</a> surrounding the earth in the center. They assumed that the Sun, Moon, and planets were spherical and not disc-shaped. They also thought that the illumination of the Moon and planets was caused by <a href="sunlight">sunlight</a>, that <a href="lunar%20eclipse">lunar eclipse</a>s occurred when the Earth obstructed sunlight falling onto the Moon, and that a <a href="solar%20eclipse">solar eclipse</a> occurred when the Moon obstructed sunlight from reaching the Earth. Although others disagreed with his model, Wang Chong accurately described the <a href="water%20cycle">water cycle</a> of the <a href="evaporation">evaporation</a> of water into clouds.
Cartography, ships, and vehicles.
Evidence found in Chinese literature, and archeological evidence, show that <a href="cartography">cartography</a> existed in China before the Han. Some of the earliest Han maps discovered were ink-penned silk maps found amongst the <a href="Mawangdui%20Silk%20Texts">Mawangdui Silk Texts</a> in a 2nd-century-BC tomb. The general <a href="Ma%20Yuan%20%28Han%20dynasty%29">Ma Yuan</a> created the world's first known <a href="raised-relief%20map">raised-relief map</a> from rice in the 1st century. This date could be revised if the tomb of Emperor <a href="Qin%20Shi%20Huang">Qin Shi Huang</a> is excavated and the account in the "Records of the Grand Historian" concerning a model map of the empire is proven to be true.
Although the use of the <a href="Scale%20%28map%29">graduated scale</a> and <a href="grid%20reference">grid reference</a> for maps was not thoroughly described until the published work of <a href="Pei%20Xiu">Pei Xiu</a> (AD 224–271), there is evidence that in the early 2nd century, cartographer Zhang Heng was the first to use scales and grids for maps.
Han dynasty Chinese sailed in a variety of ships different from those of previous eras, such as the <a href="Lou%20chuan">tower ship</a>. The <a href="Junk%20%28ship%29">"junk" design</a> was developed and realized during the Han era. Junk ships featured a square-ended <a href="Bow%20%28ship%29">bow</a> and <a href="stern">stern</a>, a flat-bottomed <a href="Hull%20%28watercraft%29">hull</a> or <a href="Carvel%20%28boat%20building%29">carvel-shaped</a> hull with no <a href="keel">keel</a> or <a href="sternpost">sternpost</a>, and <a href="Bulkhead%20%28partition%29">solid transverse bulkheads</a> in the place of <a href="Boat%20building">structural ribs</a> found in Western vessels. Moreover, Han ships were the first in the world to be steered using a <a href="rudder">rudder</a> at the stern, in contrast to the simpler <a href="steering%20oar">steering oar</a> used for riverine transport, allowing them to sail on the high seas.
Although ox-carts and chariots were previously used in China, the <a href="wheelbarrow">wheelbarrow</a> was first used in Han China in the 1st century BC. Han artwork of horse-drawn chariots shows that the Warring-States-Era heavy wooden yoke placed around a horse's chest was replaced by the softer "breast strap". Later, during the <a href="Northern%20Wei">Northern Wei</a> (386–534), the fully developed <a href="horse%20collar">horse collar</a> was invented.
Medicine.
Han-era medical physicians believed that the human body was subject to the same forces of nature that governed the greater universe, namely the <a href="cosmological">cosmological</a> cycles of yin and yang and the <a href="Wuxing%20%28Chinese%20philosophy%29">five phases</a>. Each <a href="Zang-fu">organ of the body</a> was associated with a particular phase. Illness was viewed as a sign that "<a href="qi">qi</a>" or "vital energy" channels leading to a certain organ had been disrupted. Thus, Han-era physicians prescribed medicine that was believed to counteract this imbalance. 
For example, since the wood phase was believed to promote the fire phase, medicinal ingredients associated with the wood phase could be used to heal an organ associated with the fire phase. Besides dieting, Han physicians also prescribed <a href="moxibustion">moxibustion</a>, <a href="acupuncture">acupuncture</a>, and <a href="calisthenics">calisthenics</a> as methods of maintaining one's health. When <a href="surgery">surgery</a> was performed by the Chinese physician <a href="Hua%20Tuo">Hua Tuo</a> (d. AD 208), he used <a href="anesthesia">anesthesia</a> to numb his patients' pain and prescribed a rubbing ointment that allegedly sped the process of healing surgical wounds. Whereas the physician <a href="Zhang%20Zhongjing">Zhang Zhongjing</a> ( – ) is known to have written the "<a href="Shanghan%20lun">Shanghan lun</a>" ("Dissertation on Typhoid Fever"), it is thought that both he and Hua Tuo collaborated in compiling the "<a href="Shennong%20Ben%20Cao%20Jing">Shennong Ben Cao Jing</a>" medical text.
